newsitem.title: Slovakia: Household consumption boosts Slovak GDP growth.
newsitem.headline: Household consumption boosts Slovak GDP growth.

text.p: Slovak gross domestic product (GDP) rose 6.9 percent year-on-year in second quarter 1996, boosted by an 8.2 percent growth in household consumption, the Statistical Bureau (SUSR) said on Wednesday.
Last year, second quarter GDP grew 7.1 percent, slightly above growth in household consumption of 7.0 percent, the SUSR said.
The Bureau said it had revised down its forecast for GDP growth for the whole of 1996 to 7.0 percent from 7.1 percent.

Analysts said the latest figures were in line with expectations, as the negative aspects of Slovakia's foreign trade deficit of 31 billion crowns ($1.01 billion) for the first seven months of the year had to be taken into account.
"There is a danger that the GDP has been driven too much by household consumption rather than other factors," Charlie Robertson of London analysts Hilfe, told Reuters.
"It seems that there will be further pressure on the central bank to help correct this," he added.
GDP in the first half of this year rose a real 7.1 percent. Full 1995 GDP grew by 7.4 percent and household consumption for the whole year increased by 3.4 percent.
"I would say a figure of between six to seven percent GDP growth is more realistic," Robertson said.
